list.name: Christmas Storyteller
list.about: In the Rick and Morty episode 'Anatomy Park,' the Christmas Storyteller is shown as one of the attractions. His curious fact is that he tells the story of the first Christmas on a microscopic level, using a miniaturized nativity scene inside a homeless man named Ruben. This unusual concept combines the holiday theme with the show's signature dark humor and scientific elements, making it a memorable and unconventional portrayal of the Christmas story.

list.name: Cookies Guy
list.about: The Cookies Guy is a character introduced in the episode 'Interdimensional Cable 2: Tempting Fate.' His curious fact is that he possesses a unique ability to transform his body into a living tray of cookies. This unusual and absurd power showcases the show's trademark blend of surrealism and bizarre humor. The Cookies Guy's appearance adds to the eclectic cast of characters in the Rick and Morty universe and leaves viewers with a memorable and amusing impression.

list.name: Crossy
list.about: Crossy is a character who appears in the Rick and Morty episode 'Total Rickall.' His curious fact is that he is a crosswalk guard in an alien dimension. This seemingly ordinary occupation becomes a catalyst for chaos in the episode when a parasite invasion occurs, leading to the creation of false memories and the infiltration of the Smith family's lives. Crossy's role as a crosswalk guard takes on a humorous twist, emphasizing the show's ability to find comedy in unexpected places.

list.name: Female Scorpion
list.about: The Female Scorpion is a character that appears in the episode 'Auto Erotic Assimilation.' Her curious fact is that she is a member of an alien species known as Scroopy Noopers, who have a unique ability to communicate by emitting musical tones through their tail. This distinctive form of communication adds an intriguing layer to the character and showcases the show's creativity in designing diverse extraterrestrial species.

list.name: Floaty Bloody Manâ€™s Daughter
list.about: Floaty Bloody Man's Daughter is a character mentioned in the Rick and Morty episode 'Raising Gazorpazorp.' Her curious fact is that she is the daughter of a character called Floaty Bloody Man, who is depicted as a floating disembodied head covered in blood. While Floaty Bloody Man's Daughter does not appear directly in the episode, her presence is alluded to, adding to the bizarre and macabre elements that are characteristic of the show.

list.name: Goomby
list.about: Goomby is a character that appears in the Rick and Morty episode 'Meeseeks and Destroy.' His curious fact is that he is a member of a race of aliens known as Gazorpians, who have a unique physiology. Gazorpians possess multiple sets of arms, enabling them to perform intricate tasks and gestures. Goomby's physical characteristics add to the show's imaginative portrayal of various alien species and contribute to the visual diversity of the Rick and Morty universe.

list.name: Hairspray Fan
list.about: The Hairspray Fan is a character introduced in the Rick and Morty episode 'Ricksy Business.' Their curious fact is that they are an avid fan of the interdimensional pop star named Fart. Fart is a telepathic, gas-based lifeform who plays a significant role in the episode. The Hairs pray Fan's devotion to this unique and unconventional music genre reflects the show's ability to create bizarre and memorable cultural references within its vast multiverse.

list.name: Jesus Christ
list.about: Jesus Christ is a character mentioned in the Rick and Morty episode 'Something Ricked This Way Comes.' His curious fact is that he runs a competing store to the devil's cursed antique shop, named 'Needful Things.' This reference to Jesus Christ in the show highlights its willingness to playfully incorporate religious figures into its satirical and irreverent storytelling, adding an extra layer of humor and social commentary.

list.name: Josh
list.about: Josh is a character who appears in the Rick and Morty episode 'Get Schwifty.' His curious fact is that he is an ordinary Earth musician who becomes a prominent figure in a worldwide crisis when giant heads appear in the sky and demand an original hit song. Josh's unexpected rise to fame and his role in saving the world exemplify the show's penchant for blending ordinary and extraordinary elements in its storytelling, creating unexpected and entertaining narratives.

list.name: Josh's Sister
list.about: Josh's Sister is a character mentioned in the Rick and Morty episode 'Get Schwifty.' Her curious fact is that she is an aspiring singer who is overshadowed by her brother's sudden rise to fame during the giant head crisis. While her character does not appear directly in the episode, her presence adds depth to the narrative and serves as a commentary on the dynamics of fame and sibling relationships.

list.name: Leah
list.about: Leah is a character mentioned in the Rick and Morty episode 'Ricksy Business.' Her curious fact is that she is a member of the 'Cronenberg World' resistance, a group of survivors in an alternate dimension where humanity has been transformed into grotesque, Cronenberg-like creatures. Leah's role as a resistance fighter adds to the dark and dystopian themes explored in the episode, showcasing the show's ability to tackle serious subject matter while maintaining its signature humor.

list.name: Marcus
list.about: Marcus is a character mentioned in the Rick and Morty episode 'Something Ricked This Way Comes.' His curious fact is that he is the person who sold Jerry the cursed microscope from the devil's antique shop. Marcus' unwitting involvement in Jerry's misfortune adds to the interconnectedness of the show's various storylines and reinforces the consequences of the characters' choices within the multiverse.

list.name: Mike Johnson
list.about: Mike Johnson is a character mentioned in the Rick and Morty episode 'Close Rick-Counters of the Rick Kind.' His curious fact is that he is an alternate version of Morty from a dimension where everyone looks like Eric Stoltz's character in the film 'Mask.' While Mike Johnson does not appear directly in the episode, his existence as an alternate Morty showcases the show's penchant for exploring diverse dimensions and alternate versions of characters.

list.name: Mr. Celery & Friends
list.about: Mr. Celery & Friends is a group of characters mentioned in the Rick and Morty episode 'Close Rick-Counters of the Rick Kind.' Their curious fact is that they are a parody of the popular children's TV show 'Mr. Potato Head and Friends.' This reference adds a layer of nostalgia and humor to the episode, highlighting the show's ability to playfully subvert familiar cultural icons and incorporate them into its unique universe.

list.name: Musical Fan
list.about: The Musical Fan is a character introduced in the Rick and Morty episode 'Ricksy Business.' Their curious fact is that they are a dedicated fan of the interdimensional music sensation called 'Fart.' Fart is a telepathic, gas-based lifeform who plays a significant role in the episode. The Musical Fan's passion for Fart's music represents the show's exploration of diverse musical genres and its ability to create unusual and captivating fictional artists within its narrative.

list.name: Phantom of the Opera Fan
list.about: The Phantom of the Opera Fan is a character mentioned in the Rick and Morty episode 'Ricksy Business.' Their curious fact is that they are a devoted fan of the theatrical production 'Phantom of the Opera.' This reference showcases the show's ability to incorporate elements of popular culture and fandom into its storytelling, creating relatable and humorous connections to the real world within its fantastical multiverse.

list.name: Phoenixperson
list.about: Phoenixperson is a character introduced in the Rick and Morty episode 'The Rickshank Rickdemption.' Their curious fact is that Phoenixperson is the resurrected and cybernetically enhanced version of Birdperson, a close friend of Rick Sanchez. Following Birdperson's demise in the episode 'The Wedding Squanchers,' he is reborn as Phoenixperson, embodying themes of rebirth, transformation, and the show's exploration of mortality and friendship.

list.name: Private Smith
list.about: Private Smith is a character mentioned in the Rick and Morty episode 'The Rickchurian Mortydate.' Their curious fact is that they are a soldier who becomes trapped in a sentient oil pit during a war in an alien dimension. Private Smith's unfortunate fate highlights the show's ability to incorporate dark and tragic elements into its narrative, exploring the consequences of interdimensional conflicts and the toll they take on individuals.

list.name: Professor Sanchez
list.about: Professor Sanchez is a character mentioned in the Rick and Morty episode 'The Ricklantis Mixup.' Their curious fact is that they are a version of Rick Sanchez who works as a professor in an alternate dimension. This depiction of Rick as a professor showcases the show's ability to explore different facets of the character's persona and its fascination with the multiverse's infinite possibilities, where even a brilliant scientist like Rick can have a radically different occupation.

list.name: Ramamama Lord
list.about: Ramamama Lord is a character mentioned in the Rick and Morty episode 'The Ricks Must Be Crazy.' Their curious fact is that they are a god-like figure worshiped by the sentient beings living inside Rick's spaceship battery. The Ramamama Lord's existence highlights the show's ability to create complex mythologies and belief systems within its expansive multiverse, blurring the lines between science and religion in typical Rick and Morty fashion.
